int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *sem_prop)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    sem_prop->value = sem->current_value;

int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *bin_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(bin_prop);

    memset(bin_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_bin_sem_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_bin_sem_table, token);

        strncpy(bin_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(bin_prop->name) - 1);
        bin_prop->creator = record->creator;
        return_code       = OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, bin_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}

explanation: No code fragments require investigation for potential self-call (direct or indirect recursion). The macro expands to a call to the inline function OS_ObjectIndexFromToken which simply returns token->obj_idx (no calls). The only other call site shown is OS_BinSemGetInfo calling OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl (one-way). There are no function pointers in the semaphore record that could cause an indirect callback, and no other functions in the provided fragments call OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl. Therefore there is no evidence of direct or indirect recursion to investigate.
